content.body: Any work on multitouch gesture support?
What, like some kind of multitouch event?
What would the API for that look like?
AryehGregor: Yeah. Mozilla has a few, the iPhone browser has also some support.
https://developer.mozilla.org/En/DOM/Mouse_gesture_events
Interesting.
Dunno.
http://developer.apple.com/safari/library/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/SafariJSRef/TouchEvent/TouchEvent.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40001482-CH4-SW1
AryehGregor: well, yeah. That's going to be pretty fundamental very soon, with devices like the iPad popping up everywhere, I'm sure.
Is HTML really supposed to add new input events for every new type of input device that comes along?
I guess so.
I'm afraid there might be some problem with patents, though. Apple seems to claim ownership of a few of these, more or less.
AryehGregor: I would think so. Otherwise, the goal of webapps taking over the world doesn't make a lot of sense if the only way of using newer devices is to write a native app.
Well, we have the W3C Patent Policy to handle the patents.
If they have any, they have to declare them when the feature gets to Working Draft, and say whether they'll license them royalty-free.
Great. I'm not sure what is the situation: Android and Nokia n900 do not support things like "pinch" to zoom (even though the hardware is capable), but Windows 7 does.
I've heard claims Apple says they feel they have a patent on that one. Would they license it to MS? Maybe.
If it's in a Working Draft, they have to say so, yes or no.
Royalty-free for all implementations of the standard, or not.
And if not, they could be kicked out of the Working Group, as I understand it, if the patent covers "essential claims" (although I might misremember).
(this is all W3C stuff, not WHATWG)
I see. I really hope there is going to be some work toward multitouch, then.
You could propose it on the whatwg list.
multitouch would be better addressed to the www-dom list
AryehGregor: OK, I'll check the archives and suggest the topic.
Okay, listen to Hixie.
Not me.  :)
but first we need a spec for single-touch, and, like, mice. and keyboards, even.
Heh.
There was some discussion on the list: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-dom/2009AprJun/0134.html and Nokia, more recently http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-dom/2009OctDec/0041.html
But not much since October.
Hasn't it already been established that text/html-sandboxed is *not* mime-sniffed as text/html in legacy browsers?
I don't think it's been established as true under all circumstances beyond any doubt.
I saw someone say that IE might pose a problem if the URL ends in .html or such.
Hmm, k.
IE will potentially sniff even if the query part ends in .html
so tricky to defend against
Just don't have the file end in .html?
I mean, for the common case of serving comments, it'll be a .php or .aspx commonly.
Re: “A header element is intended to usually contain the section's heading (an h1–h6 element or an hgroup element), but this is not required”
“this is not required” seems to mean the header doesn’t have to contain a heading, but a section generally should have a heading, right?
is “this is not required” for multiple headings in one section & web app use where the section lacks a heading?
or are untitled sections not as ‘to be avoided’ as I thought?
TabAtkins: php is often set up to respond even if you tack on arbitrary stuff to the URL
TabAtkins: and if your URL takes a query parameter, and IE looks at that, you can tack on .html via a query
http://example.com/script.php?foo=bar.html
That's the most ridiculous bullshit I've ever heard of, and I hate whoever did that with a fiery passion.
the IE team? or the PHP team?
I don't see how either could be any more of a hate target than they are already...
IE team.
so up til now, you've been totally cool with the 90s / early 2000s IE team
but now that you have learned this one additional fact...
No.  But I hate the specific person in charge of the decision to activate sniffing if the query params happen to end in ".html".
It was a generalized hate before.  But now it's focused on that one person.
Hixie: what does a datalist element with no option children represent?
or to put it another way, what's the use case for a datalist element with no option children?

a zero-yen house after the collapse of the economy ;)

dude pretty much sits around all day and barely even opens his eyes when you pet him
maybe a dudette could help him move in a better place instead of his shabby shelter. who knows :)

implication of the sign is, don't feed him, because he's too fat already

but being that it's Japan, even signs instructing people not to fee fat tomcats have to be polite
anyway, Naoko has some pictures
I'll have to come by myself to see that
I'm planning to come to Japan. No date defined yet. Probably in April. not sure
karlcow: would be great to see you
yep yep
impatient
ラメンとなまビウ
ponders how to solve the microdata-to-rdf problem
it isn't solved already?
othermaciej: issues were brought up
sadness
specifically, how to convert the following:
s
I don't think I am clear enough on the semantics of Microdata to help
I imagine the problem is that the contents of div#x are being interpreted in two different ways?
yeah
not a problem for microdata, but when converting to rdf it causes an issue
because they need a URL for the properties
any rdf people here? Is there any meaning to the concept of a triple being stated twice?
e.g. if I write (in Turtle): <about:1> <about:2> <about:3> . <about:1> <about:2> <about:3> .
is that any different than just saying it once?
The spec mentions the canvas dropshadow is Gaussian blur with defined SD.  Does that mean compliant browsers shouldl be pixel identical? (not counting precision errors).
images made of dropshadows  http://screamingduck.com/Lerc/jspic/
not counting precisions errors, yes, more or less
I'm not sure who's wrong then but those pics render differently in FF and Safari.
Hard to tell because I'm generating the images in flash and its blur might be different again.
They make a funky testcase though :-)
heh
Next up is attempting JS+Canvas only Video.
foolip: if you're around, I'd be interested in your input on the edits to the microdata section
that i just generated
i can produce a diff before i check in if that would help
Where do people get this idea that HTML5 needs to make conforming everything that has ever been conforming?
HTML 2.0 doctypes aren't conforming per 3.2
and 2.0 and 3.2 doctypes aren't conforming per 4.0
hsivonen: HTML4 Transitional documents aren't conforming HTML4 Strict, even

I think people are starting with an assumption that IETF mime type registration updates can never make previous content of that MIME type noncomforming, combined with the fact that HTML5 obsoletes the old registration and does not explicitly mention the old versions
to conclude that
(I do not know if there is really such an IETF rule or if it applies to the W3C's inline registrations)
there's a whole section on older versions
"History", in the introduction
then it seems like the logic being applied is fallacious if it is along the lines I said
http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2854 explicitly says it's not compatible with HTML2, even
and HTML3:
Wouldn't it be sufficient to say something along the lines of: "The text/html content type may be used to label documents that conform to previous levels of HTML."
Note that [HTML20] included an optional "level" parameter; in
practice, this parameter was never used and has been removed from
this specification.  [HTML30] also suggested a "version"
parameter; in practice, this parameter also was never used and has
been removed from this specification.
s/previous levels/a previous level/
hsivonen: maybe. would that mean you can't write a validator unless you implement every version?
i think the spec already allows you to bail if the doctype is some older version's, no?
or did i remove that
Hixie: at least the spec allows validators to go into a legacy checking mode
Hixie: even if the MIME registration permitted HTML 2.0, I have no intention to support HTML 2.0 validation
holy crap, this is a must in 2854:
Implementors of text/html interpreters must be prepared to be
"bug-compatible" with popular browsers in order to work with many
HTML documents available the Internet.
you know, i really can't see anything in 2854 that is any different than what html5 does, really
Hixie: how did an anti-competitive statement like that get into an RFC edited by L. Masinter?
so i don't understand the problem at all
hopefully bugs have been filed explaining what parts of 2854 i need to include to make things better
assuming 2854 is ok
which it presumably is
Hixie: it would mean you couldn't write a validator for conformance to the text/html content type without implementing every version, but you could still write an HTML5 validator
hmm. the full screen controls in http://jilion.com/sublime/video are different from the full window controls
are the full screen controls Safari-native?
any webkit peeps here? tried on #webkit but no informative replies :)

I think Larry has a point about overspecification being anti-competitive - it's true if you are more worried about protecting the 0.01% implementation from the 2% implementation than the 2% implementation from the 60% implementation
I can see the point, but it seems to me that in practice, having undocumented but de facto necessary behaviors is more anti-competitive
overspecifying the unnecessary could be anti-competitive
but the thing is that whenever top 4 or even top 3 UAs have converged on a behavior, someone somewhere starts relying on it
othermaciej: actually, roc made a good point about that
othermaciej: which is that over-specification is harmless in practice
othermaciej: since if it's not required to compete, you can just ignore it
of course, US antitrust law (and probably European too) would be more worried about a 60% vs 2% situation than a 2% vs 0.01% situation
othermaciej: and if it is, it helps the underdog
othermaciej: so in fact, it's better to overspecify
Hixie: sometimes, it's really hard to tell which parts of HTML5 are known to be required to compete and which parts aren't
Hixie: my underlying model is that the far underdog (as opposed to the still-significant underdog) does not have the resources to independently determine what parts of the spec are required
Hixie: so one could argue you waste resources by implementing parts that aren't competitive requirements
nor the resources to just implement the whole spec
Hixie: and developing the knowledge of which parts are hard and which soft requirements for competitiveness partially comes back to the reverse engineering problem
i view the spec as being like a high resolution image
and an implementation as being like an approximation of that image
although it's still better than just reverse engineering, because the spec gives you a hypothesis
now there are two ways to do this:
fill in each pixel one by one, or fill in the broad brush strokes and slowly improve each bit
if you do the former, then (a) you'll never be done and (b) over-specifying is a bad idea
if you do the other one, then you'll ship soon, and you'll immediately get feedback about which parts to try to paint in more detail
I think Larry's incorrect premise is that the level of benefit to #300 vs #4 is as important as the level of benefit to #4 vs #1
and over time you approximate the spec in more and more detail
so i stand by roc's premise
that's not how we tend to evaluate whether a market is competitive, at least in law, economics or common-sense understanding
othermaciej: indeed, we'd be lucky (in terms of preserving freedom and choice) to have even a 5th major impl.
well, we have a 4-and-a-halfth at least
the and a half part fools people into thinking there are actually 5
so that stuff that is WebKit only, gets promoted as Safari, Chrome and Chrome Frame and counted as 3
-and-a-half probably overestimates the degree of difference actually

I think citing Safari, Chrome and Chrome Frame is only relevant in terms of telling content authors the size of their potential deployment target; definitely is not 3 separate implementations for standards purposes
(nor do Safari on iPhone, Safari on iPad, Arora, Epiphany, OmniWeb, iCab, Sunrise Browser, etc all count as additional implementations)
man, even the w3c wasn't this arrogant when we discussed the w3c and the whatwg working together on html5
the ietf people are making me have renewed respect for the w3c
how dare they!
If IETF doesn't offer patent protection, what's the upside of taking the Web Socket protocol to the IETF?
none as far as i can tell
does the W3C require the protocol to be an IETF spec in order to get the PP on the API?
(in theory more review)
the W3C does not require the protocol to be an IETF spec at all
it's only not in the W3C spec because the IETF whined to the W3C than the W3C were overstepping their agreement on who would work on what
IETF requires patent disclosure at least (IIRC)
othermaciej: as far as i can tell it requires patent disclosure of patents that the contributors know about
and minimum RAND licensing, though a group can ask for RF commitments
and i certainly don't know jack about google's patents
I don't remember the details that clearly
what's the IETF definition of RAND?
it's somewhere in the process RFC
interesting. seeing green on dev.w3.org: http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/WebTiming/
hsivonen: "RAND" is not free-software compatible, so the definition is moot
Hixie: I know RAND is neither reasonable nor non-discriminatory. I was curious, though.
the relevant RFCs are linked to from every RFC's boilerplate
well. I say "linked to". But of course the IETF is stuck using text/plain, so I really mean "mentioned".

The problem with RAND is that what is considered reasonable is left entirely up to the patent holder, and the definition of non-discriminitory is that the fee applies equally to everyone, despite discriminating against those who can't be expected to afford the "reasonable" fee
the fee isn't the problem, when it comes to free software
but yeah
I would make fun of them for using plaintext, but I do all my editing in emacs
which I think folks on my team find equally laughable
othermaciej: me too, but i edit _html_ :-P
longs for the day when C++ can be edited the way Java is edited in Eclipse JDT
does java not have macros?
Hixie: it doesn't
i'd have thought that was the biggest problem with making "real" c++ IDEs
Hixie: it is
k
Hixie: templates, too
Hixie: and typedefs
i thought java had both of those now
Hixie: with Java, the semantic role of any piece of syntax is decidable from a sane grammar
without having to process any include files
Java has generics, which offer the benefits of casual templates
right
but generics don't support all the crazy computation in the compile phase stuff
yay. my C++ compile phase completed. now I can edit.
to make a C++ IDE you have to parse all the C++ you are working with, but I don't think macros are a significantly larger part of the challenge than anything else
othermaciej: i would have thought that for an IDE's purposes, it'd be an issue because you'd have to keep track of what came from what
incremental Java compiles as you edit are also awesome compared to waiting for a Firefox build
othermaciej: i.e. it's not like you can just quickly reparse the current bit and say "oh yeah, that's an identifier"
the hard parts are aspects of the grammar that are ambiguous unless you know which identifiers are types, or the like
othermaciej: you have to keep track of everything and how it corresponded to macros and so on
othermaciej: that part of C++ language design is insane
Hixie: the preprocessor processing model is way simpler than parsing actual C++ itself
othermaciej: fair enough
I have been using C++ professionally for something like 12 years now and I'm still occasionally learning things that totally surprise me
Hixie: you were right that making streamless about:blank fire onload is a pain
heh
all this onload firing machinery wants to see a stream-bound request
the problem in the spec would be making sure it doesn't fire twice
not really sure how to do that
since when you create the about:blank, you don't know that you're _not_ going to load a page
and when you don't load a page, well, you didn't load a page. There's nothing to hook onto to fire the load.
Hixie: I put the about:blank creation on the code path that with any other URL kicks off the first actual load
Hixie: and if the browser context hasn't had anything loaded to it and is about to load about:blank, I generate a document and return early
yeah i wish i could do that too, but the spec ended up too far from that to really do it sanely without a lot of tweaking
invoking the machinery for DOMContentLoaded is done
but when I try to fake onload, I keep hitting assertions that want to see a network request
so I guess I'll end up faking one
or maybe I'll make the loading machinery have a flag that tells it it's actually loading a fake about:blank
special cases...
Hixie: can XBL2 do evil things and inject scripts into about:blank synchronously with element creation?
assuming you inject enough stuff into the document that it has bindings at all, i guess so
about:blank isn't special in that sense
Hixie: can you inject bindings into about:blank somehow?
sure, just inject a <link> to a style sheet or something
or loadBindingsDocument()
er, loadBindingDocument() even
Hixie: How do you inject the <link> before the sync about:blank has already been created?
actually i guess a style sheet won't do it, that's always async
wait, _before_ about:blank is created?
about:blank is created as soon as you create the browsing context
nothing can premept that
preempt
Hixie: in any case, having scripts run synchronously with element insertion to the DOM seems like huge badness
points to mutation events
Hixie: what's the sync/async story for bindings that haven't loaded by the time a bound element goes live?
(btw, you can bind elements that aren't even in the document)
Hixie: mutation events don't fire for parser-inserted stuff
so, just for the record, i'm literally answering by reading teh spec here
wait, parser-created?
i thought we were talking about about:blank
i'm confused
Hixie: isn't the fake about:blank conceptually parser-created as far as mutition event craziness goes?
I guess I should read the whole XBL2 spec one of these days
I saw some scary code pertaining to XBL1
hsivonen: it's just created, there's no parser
hsivonen: i don't see how mutation events would be relevant here
hsivonen: there's no way to see the about:blank doc before it's completely ready
you can't load binding documents before about:Blank is done
what's the CSS selector syntax for saying, "element of class foo NOT followed by adjacent sibling of class bar"?
MikeSmith: .foo:not(:matches(#~.bar)) if my proposal goes through, but it's not possible currently
Hixie: so there is no way to express it currently?
oh
you just said that
sorry
well shit
that sucks
hsivonen: http://www.mozilla.org/projects/xbl/xbl2.html#binding is the key part
hsivonen: the few paragraphs up to the first example in that section
MikeSmith: it'd be a perf nightmare
MikeSmith: you'd need one rule to match all .foo and then another overriding .foo + .bar
at the moment
GarethAdams|Home: nah he wants to style the .foo, not the .bar
of course, and my idea was broken in any case

Hixie: "If the binding document has yet to be (fully) loaded when it becomes known that the binding applies, then the user agent must wait until all running scripts have completed before attaching the binding." looks like a huge can of worms to me
it's too early
Hixie: oops. never mind
hsivonen: that's just saying (in terms that predate the html5's event loop spec) to queue a task instead of preempting a script
hsivonen: to keep things predictable
Hixie: am I reading this correctly that binding loads race with script loads?
yes
fun
i was young, what can i say
but not making it so would be painful, I guess
not sure how else to do it, yeah
xbl2 is still young too
short of doing what we do with css
at least in implementation years
which is painful too
othermaciej: yeah sometime this year i'll take the feedback collected and do another CR
I guess blocking the parser on inline scripts if there are pending bindings would be doable
othermaciej: (sometime after sicking sends some more feedback)
also, it looks like a sane XBL2 impl. is going to continue to need the Gecko scriptrunner facility
I hope we get a chance to start on it soon but we only have bandwidth for so many architecture-level changes at a time
(i have 52 e-mails in the XBL folder)
so I guess we aren't getting rid of that
othermaciej: yeah, it's just not as high priority as a lot of the other new stuff
after our current semi-stealth one the next big change will probably be one of HTML5 parsing, XBL2, or refactoring the render tree
i vote for parsing
wonders if other engines have a facility to queue tasks that go into a local task queue that is executed at a safe point between now and the next event loops spin
but more than any of those things I want to see implementation of more HTML5 elements and form controls
I'd love to see new form controls in Gecko *and* a story for styling them
hsivonen: you mean like the spec's "synchronous section"?
Hixie: XBL2 spec's?
oh HTML5's
yeah, html5
Hixie: it says: "A synchronous section never mutates the DOM, runs any script, or has any other side-effects."
so no
ah
the whole point of scriptrunners is that they can do that kind of scary stuff
man, i fixed both session history's async hairball and the microdata sub-vocab-in-rdf issue today. i'm on a roll.
i hope this is indicative of a renewed level of productivity
hsivonen: right now those are used to do async stuff that needs to inspect the DOM without being racy against running scripts
hsivonen: basically it's a synchronisation section for other threads
at some point i might have to add (e.g. for xbl) a new thing about the same place, like a high-priority queue or something
so far i've avoided it
ok, w3c microdata editorial stuff, let's see
the idea of scriptrunners is that they look synchronous from the POV of scripts but are deferred from the POV of C++
othermaciej: any suggestions for how i should describe microdata and 2dcontext in terms of "context and rationale"?
(it's one of the things i have to put in the status-of-this-document section)
Hixie: can you give an example of text along those lines in another document's sotd for a point of reference?
I am not very familiar with the sotd requirements
it's the paragraph starting "This specification is a module that forms part of the HTML5 series" in the microdata spec currently
I'm checking what Web Storage says in the equivalent place
I don't see any text analogous to that in Web Storage, it goes straight from the responsible Working Group paragraph to the patent policy paragraph
uh, yes indeedy, i appear to have omitted the context section in that spec
Workers says "This specification is intended to specify a part of the Web platform closely related to HTML5. It is defined in a separate document primarily to ease the cognitive load on reviewers."
WebSocket says "This specification is being developed in conjunction with an Internet Draft for a wire protocol, the Web Socket Protocol, available from the IETF at the following location"
i can use the web worker text if you like
I would say something like "This specification was developed in tandem with HTML5 and is intended to be used in conjunction with it"
or something like the Workers spec, though maybe people would get irked at "closely related"
that works
the sentence I suggested seems more fact-based and so hopefully less controversial
tis in
though if you can predict what's going to be controversial, you're a better man than i
sometimes I am able to guess
certainly not always
signing off for a bit to debug something, will be back
figcaption, etc., pale in comparison when you consider that the token for denoting a person's name is called fn
always assumes fn means "file name"
I assume it means "function"
fullname
or that it's a symbol for the n-th fibonacci number
Or an abbreviation of fnord
an abbreviation of what?
your sentence got cut off it looks like

othermaciej: i'm confused about how to handle all the cross-references
like the references to "boolean attributes", or "HTML element", or "applicable specification"

k
not ok to claim to be part of it

its context paragraph is "This specification is an extension to the HTML5 language. All normative content in the HTML5 specification, unless specifically overridden by this specification, is intended to be the basis for this specification."

joy

about three weeks
"Since previously, HTML content that invoked quirks mode *was* conforming, we can't make it non-conforming."
Can't we?
Of course not, because that's not allowed
Not allowed by... the axiomatic proof?
If it was allowed, then we could make old content non-conforming, which we can't do because it's not allowed
therefore we can't allow it
Proof by contradiction
If it's not proof by axiom, it isn't valid
I think that statement follows from the imo misguided way media types are drafted to work
btw, I noticed data URLs were discussed at some point here
they do have fragment identifiers
Only in Opera, apparently
fragment identifiers depend on the media type, not URI scheme
well, Firefox is buggy
And webkit
also buggy

Maybe it's actually a (sensible) desire to guarantee backward compatibility within media types, but twisted by a (incorrect) notion that content conformance and interoperable operation are tied together
see RFC 3986

Dashiva, people who claim things like that need to realise that a new specification making things non-conformng with respect to that particular specification, doesn't make those things non-conforming with respect to other specifications.

It's better than fucking up every URI scheme totally
gsnedders, RFC 3986 explicitly says that URI schemes can't special-case fragment syntax, as annevk pointed out.
AryehGregor: Yes, but it isn't just fragment syntax that is special cased. It the whole URI-reference that is special cased.
Really?
looks more closely
If the string starts with javascript: or data:, it isn't treated as a URI at all
It seems like RFC 3986 allows URIs like data: and javascript:, with the path component defined as path-rootless.
In what way is it not treated as a URI at all?  It looks like a URI to me.
Indeed.
AryehGregor: It's not actually parsed as a URL. The leading string is stripped, and pct-encoding is decoded.
AryehGregor: <iframe src="javascript://foobar%0Adocument.write('a')"></iframe>
So how is that not parsing as a URL?  It's just a URL that doesn't use the hierarchy syntax.
RFC 3986 allows those as URIs.
Basically just a leading "something:" following by anything you like, and then a fragment.
AryehGregor: Because we'd have to separate it up into segments, and would only apy attention to path
Well, you do.  The path is just one segment, namely, the whole URL other than the initial "data:" and the trailing fragment.
And query part
Yeah, that too.
Was about to say.
AryehGregor: No, we don't.
Look at that example above
AryehGregor: The whole thing is in the host
What about it?  The path is "//foobar\ndocument.write('a')".
No, there's no host.
How not?
A path can't start with //
Because an authority starts with //
URI         = scheme ":" hier-part [ "?" query ] [ "#" fragment ]
thinks AryehGregor has got his ABNF wrong
hier-part   = "//" authority path-abempty
/ path-absolute
/ path-rootless
/ path-empty
path-rootless = segment-nz *( "/" segment )
It doesn't match path-absolute, path-rootless, or path-empty
segment-nz    = 1*pchar
It matches path-rootless.
pchar doesn't contain /
Hmm.
Otherwise that would be ambiguous for cases like //gsnedders.com
Touche.
javascript: URLs are just an abomination, we shouldn't try to treat them otherwise
The only alternation there that can start with // is "//" authority path-abempty
Okay, you win.
data: and javascript: don't follow URI syntax at all, so no reason to quibble over the fragment or query parts.
